Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Particle Physics Research at High Energies
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model to date was confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). However, the Standard Model as it currently exists leaves open many questions about the universe, including such fundamental questions as to why the Higgs mass has the value it has. One of the primary functions of the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment at the LHC, which remains the premier Energy Frontier particle accelerator, operating at the CERN laboratory near Geneva Switzerland, is to discover new physics beyond the Standard Model. This project will analyze data from the CMS experiment looking for signals of beyond the Standard Model. The work that will be accomplished with this award will impact three broad areas: 1) Upgrading the highly technical components of the CMS detector 2) workforce development and outreach to the broader community and 3) furthering the analysis techniques that might well discover new physics at the LHC. With the strong cooperative education program at Northeastern University, the group will continue to routinely involve undergraduates in meaningful six-month projects at CERN. The PIs will also continue their involvement with the Boston Area QuarkNet group (now in its 14th year) where they are able to reach out to local high school teachers and their students. The group members also share the excitement and knowledge of the discoveries and results with the broader public through lectures and presentations to audiences outside of particle physics.

The work funded through this award will search for a number of new particle physics sectors where there are theoretical models of beyond the SM physics. A discovery of leptoquarks would provide a link between the quark sector and the lepton sectors and help to explain why both sectors contain three generations of matter. Detection of substantial invisible decays of the Higgs boson would answer important questions about the nature of electroweak symmetry breaking. Invisible decays of the Higgs are a signature of various beyond the standard model physics theories. In these, the Higgs can interact with new heavy particles which decay into particles that are usually not detected by the experiment (like neutrinos). Limits on the invisible decay rate of the Higgs boson also provide constraints on models of Dark Matter. This project's studies also include measurements of the differential cross section measurements of Standard Model processes, such as ZZ production, and W+jets production, that have sensitivity to new physics. These studies are tightly coupled with the new physics searches because the processes they measure are important backgrounds to the specific searches targeted. The presence of a signal in any of these channels would have profound impact on our understanding of particle physics, while establishing its absence would provide important constraints on models of physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) provides the highest energy particle collisions in the world.  We have used this amazing device, together with the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) particle detector, to search for phenomena that can shed light onto our understanding of the matter composition of the universe. 

It was a great achievement when the Higgs boson was discovered at the LHC in 2012. Elementary particles acquire their mass by interacting with the Higgs field and precision measurements of the Higgs production and decay can give insight into the origin of particle masses. Beyond that, the production of two Higgs boson particles corresponds to process of self-interaction of the Higgs boson. This is extremely important to study because it gives us information on the fabric of the Higgs field itself, into which all of the mass of our universe is woven. Is the Higgs field stable? If not, how close is our universe to slipping into another state of lower energy? Our group led the first search at the LHC for the production of two Higgs bosons decaying into two Z bosons and into two b-quarks, respectively.

While the testing the Higgs mechanism allows us to deepen our understanding of the origin of known matter, from astrophysical measurements, we know that only a small fraction of the matter budget of the universe corresponds to known, or visible matter. A large component is what we call dark matter whose particle nature remains a mystery.  Our group used the data collected by the CMS detector at the LHC to look for evidence that dark matter was produced, in processes where dark matter could be produced in association with known matter, e.g. Z bosons. We found no evidence and by quantifying this absence, we furnished information to test and guide the predictions of theoretical dark matter models.

Searches for new physics are based on the precise understanding of the known processes (of the "standard model"), from which we must be able to differentiate the unknown ones.  Our group took a leadership role in advancing precise measurements standard model processes, such as the extensive measurement of the properties of W bosons produced in association with jets of strongly interacting particles.

The ability to do these studies relies on the efficient functioning of the CMS particle detector, which identifies a handful of different types of particles (electrons, muons, photons, hadrons) to deduce what kind of interactions took place in the center of the detector to produce them. The muon is one of the most useful particles to identify, and our group took a leadership role in the part of the CMS detector that detects muons.  During the most recent LHC shut down, we extracted our muon detectors and installed new electronics that will allow them to gather even more data when the LHC restarts with higher intensity circulating beams.

In addition to advancing our understanding of fundamental science, we were able to make advances that are advantageous for other fields.  Our study of electronics and optical fibers found examples that were resistant to radiation. Our studies of muon chamber performance identified some promising new gas mixtures for particle detectors that reduce greenhouse gas emissions. We found new applications of machine learning in building software tasked to monitoring detector performance. We trained students that were able to use their skills analyzing large data sets in other fields and that successfully applied to jobs in data science.
